awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Preempting Physical Damage from Control-Related Attacks on Smart Grids' Cyber-Physical Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Control-related attacks are a severe threat to cyber-physical systems (CPSs) such as smart grids, because they can introduce catastrophic physical damage by using malicious control commands crafted in a legitimate format. While current research efforts have focused on detecting malicious commands that lead to physical damage, the investigator proposes to preemptively prevent the damage by disrupting and misleading adversaries' preparation before they issue the malicious commands. To achieve this objective, the proposed work includes: (i) characterizing dependencies between normal activities from both the cyber and physical domains in smart grids; (ii) determining a network spoofing paradigm to disrupt adversaries' knowledge of smart grids by injecting network packets on behalf of nonexistent computing nodes; and (iii) crafting decoy measurements to mislead adversaries into designing damage-free attack strategies. The proposed work will use software-defined networking (SDN) to prevent physical damage in smart grids without changing the grids' physical infrastructure. With the wide use of SDN in different CPSs, this work may serve as the basis for future research that extends to the broader domains of CPS and Internet-of-Things, which connect devices from different applications, such as smart health and smart home. Since CPS companies are upgrading their cyberinfrastructure with advanced network technologies, this work has promising applications in real utility environments to increase their resilience.

The proposed work has the potential to transform current passive detection methods into preemptive approaches that disarm adversaries with misleading information. This work includes the following thrusts: (i) Development of interdisciplinary methods to identify dependencies between activities from the cyber and physical domains by combining data analytics and system specifications. Driven by real data collected from deep-packet network monitoring enabled by the Bro network analyzer, these methods will reveal the thorough operational logic of smart grids by integrating knowledge from different disciplines. (ii) Creation of an SDN-based platform to determine a network spoofing paradigm that resembles normal activities. By establishing interactions between the Bro network analyzer and SDN network controllers, the investigator will use the modeling of system activities to inject network traffic that is statistically indistinguishable from normal traffic to prevent adversaries from learning the true system configuration, without affecting legitimate applications. (iii) Creation of an algorithm to craft decoy measurements that mislead adversaries. To craft the application-layer payload of the spoofed packets, the investigator will model adversaries' attack preparation procedure as an optimization problem and thus determine decoy measurements that will mislead adversaries into designing attacks that target nonexistent components to thus induce little if any physical damage. (iv) Validation of the proposed preemptive approach using a cyber-physical testbed that integrates real SDN-enabled switches and power system simulations driven by real operational data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Control-related attacks are a severe threat to cyber-physical systems (CPSs) because they can introduce catastrophic physical damage using malicious control commands crafted in a legitimate format. During the life cycle of this project, we have designed a preemptive moving target defense mechanism to limit and prevent physical damage in CPSs inflicted by control-related attacks. Specifically, we have focused on CPSs that monitor and control smart grids. Our approach is very different from current research efforts that passively detect malicious commands after physical damage. We can prevent the damage by disrupting and misleading adversaries' preparation before they issue the malicious commands. To achieve this objective, we have: (i) designed and implemented a network spoofing paradigm based on software-defined networking (SDN) to disrupt adversaries' knowledge of the smart grids; and (ii) crafted decoy measurements to mislead adversaries into designing damage-free attack strategies by retrofitting existing mathematical models in power grids.

The project outcomes demonstrate a promising potential to transform current passive detection methods into preemptive approaches that disarm adversaries with misleading information. First, the proposed SDN-based platform has created a new engineering paradigm, which we refer to as physical function virtualization (PFV), which hooks network interactions with real devices to build virtual nodes. Lightweight virtual nodes built by PFV follow actual implementations of network stacks, system invariants, and physical state variations of real devices, making it challenging to distinguish them from real devices. Second, the newly-created paradigm allows for fine-grained manipulation of network communications in power grids, disrupting attackers' knowledge of target power grids without affecting existing device configuration and control operations. Third, the algorithm used to craft decoy measurements can mislead adversaries and be hard to distinguish from normal measurements. Last, to validate the proposed preemptive approach, we develop a cyber-physical testbed that integrates real SDN-enabled switches and power system simulations driven by real operational data. We not only publish the final implementation details of the testbed but also share the strawman designs and implementation, leading to the final outcome.

Before the end of this project, we further use advanced network technologies like SDN to prevent physical damage in other modern CPSs, specifically the internet of Things (IoT) that are deployed in smart home environments. We observe that a large number of IoT devices, if manipulated collectively by attackers, can cause significant disruptions to existing power systems. However, the global visibility enabled by SDN can allow us to correlate network behaviors distributed in different geographical locations and identify such global malicious trends.

The project's outcome has significantly improved undergraduate and graduate education, preparing students for the upcoming Industry 4.0 era. Despite the challenge of the COVID-19 pandemic, I created and taught two courses directly related to CPS security, i.e., ELE 108G Introduction to Cyber-Physical Security (a grand-challenge course including around 80 freshmen from four diverse colleges) and ELE 420/520 Security of Cyber-Physical Systems for both undergraduates and graduates. In addition, I actively involved undergraduate students in research projects; one of my undergraduates won the Nevada Undergraduate Research Award in 2019. Based on the outcome of this project, I held lab sessions in CPS security courses multiple times, including (i) tutorials of the Zeek network analyzer, (ii) implementation of non-intrusive false data injection attacks on simulated power grids, and (iii) leveraging Zeek network analyzer to detect the attacks. One unique outcome of this project, which was carried out through the COVID-19 pandemic, is that I have developed precious experiences teaching and guiding students in hybrid mode. To make students keep social distance, I developed an original hybrid mode in my course, allowing students to interact face-to-face in the undergraduate course with more than 80 students. Meanwhile, to increase the interactions of remote students, I used many cloud-based teaching platforms such as Gather Town to teach classes, present posters, and even social events. This hybrid mode also helped me co-advise a female Ph.D. student who has worked in Coastal Guard Academy before. Finally, this project's outcome helped me participate in community activities to interact with K-12 students and their parents. For example, in 2018 (when I worked at the University of Nevada at Reno), I attended a tech exhibit named "Engineers Make a World of Difference" organized by the American Library Association. The exhibit was held in a community including around 4% Black, 6% Asian, and 23.3% Hispanic.
